citeinfo.title: Evapotranspiration data for northwest Nevada for 2002, derived from Landsat imagery and gridded weather products
Remote Sensing Estimates of Evapotranspiration from Irrigated Agriculture, Northwestern Nevada

descript.abstract: Reporting of evapotranspiration from irrigated agriculture in Nevada and other western US states is increasingly being required for surface and groundwater use inventories, estimating historical pumpage, and supporting the evaluation of water right applications, transfers, and protests. The arid landscape of northwestern Nevada is punctuated by agricultural communities that rely on water supplied by the diversion of surface waters, groundwater, or a combination of both. Many hydrographic areas (HAs) within northwestern Nevada are entirely reliant on groundwater due to the lack of surface water, while other HAs are entirely reliant on surface water due to poor quality of groundwater. Precipitation in the form of winter snowfall largely determines the amount of surface water that is available for irrigation the following growing season. During years of insufficient surface water supplies, some basins can use supplemental groundwater in order to meet irrigation needs. Annual and monthly consumptive use from irrigated agriculture is largely a function of surface and groundwater availability, atmospheric water demand, crop type, land use and cropping changes such as fallowing and crop rotations, crop stress and disease, and water right transfers from irrigation to a new use (e.g. municipal or environmental). The use of satellite imagery is required to accurately estimate actual evapotranspiration (ET) from irrigated agriculture. Because crop type and field conditions can vary significantly in time and space, satellite imagery such as Landsat that is of sufficient spatial resolution to capture field scale conditions, is required to accurately characterize spatial and temporal variations of crop phenology, stress, and ultimately ET. Free access to satellite imagery and gridded weather data along with significant advances in processing hardware, software, and analysis, has advanced the use of satellite imagery to the forefront of ET estimation. This is especially true where water consumption from large areas has to be quantified. The objective of this study is to estimate monthly an annual ET from agricultural areas in northwestern Nevada from 2001 through 2011 using Landsat satellite imagery. Field scale ET estimates from 57 HAs are summarized multiple ways includeing a geodatabase, maps, figures, and tables. Monthly and annual ET estimates for select HAs are discussed with respect to variations in climate, water supply, and land use changes, through visualizations and summaries of spatial and temporal ET distributions. A geodatabase was constructed ET, precipitation, net ET (ET minus precipitation), and atmospheric water demand (i.e. reference ET). Landsat based ET was estimated using a land surface energy balance model, Mapping EvapoTranspiration at high Resolution with Internalized Calibration (METRIC), using Landsat 5 and Landsat 7 imagery combined with reference ET. Estimates of net ET were created by subtracting monthly precipitation from METRIC-derived ET, and seasonal estimates were generated by combining monthly ET for April-October (the regional agricultural growing season). Results highlight that a range of geographic, climatic, hydrographic, and anthropogenic factors influence ET. For example, HAs such as Mason Valley have the ability to mitigate deficiencies in surface water supplies by pumping supplemental groundwater, thereby resulting in low annual variability of ET. Conversely, Lovelock has access to limited upstream surface water storage and is not able to irrigate with groundwater due to high salinity. These factors result in Lovelock ET being highly variable in time due to drought. ET estimates derived from METRIC compare fairly well to previous estimates of well-irrigated crop ET reported by Huntington and Allen (2010) (i.e. NVET estimates). Differences in ET estimates are potentially due to the fact that previous NVET estimates assume well-irrigated conditions and the fact that METRIC also has limitations and inaccuracies. Although there are limitations and uncertainties with the METRIC model, previous Nevada studies have shown METRIC is fairly accurate for crops of alfalfa and pasture grass. Results of this work will be useful for water use inventories, groundwater use estimation, and in distinguishing how prolonged droughts and changing climate will potentially affect different HAs and agricultural communities in the future.
descript.purpose: This geodatabase contains shapefiles that contain estimates of evapotranspiration for agricultural areas within northwest Nevada and additional support data. These shapefiles contain data for the years 2001-2011, with each shapefile representing a single year.

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

attr.attrdef: This attribute was used for the processing of hydrographic areas (HAs) within the study area, in order to bypass conflicts with naming methods employed in Nevada and California.
State which contains the centroid of the polygon.
The number designator assigned to the hydrographic area (HA) in which the centroid of the polygon is located. For areas in California, the attribute is assigned a value of: “CA”.
The name assigned to the hydrographic area (HA), in which the centroid of the polygon is located.
For locations in California a hydrologic unit code (HUC) was used to denote the basin containing the polygon. Attribute utilizes that HUC8 code.
For locations in California a hydrologic unit code (HUC) was used to denote the basin containing the polygon. Attribute utilizes the name associated with the HUC8.
The number of pixels contained within the polygon.
The year for which the data was generated.
Area contained within pixel (acres)
Annual total of reference evapotranspiration (ETr) calculated for the polygon (millimeters).
Annual total of evapotranspiration (ET) calculated for the polygon (millimeters).
Annual average of fraction of reference evapotranspiration (ETrF) (unitless)
Annual total of precipitation (millimeters).
attr.attrdefs: PRISM Climate Group, Oregon State University, http://prism.oregonstate.edu, created 4 Feb 2004.

attr.attrdef: Annual total of ET with the annual total of precipitation subtracted (millimeters).
Seasonal total of reference evapotranspiration (ETr) for the polygon (millimeters).
Seasonal total of evapotranspiration (ET) for the polygon (millimeters).
Seasonal average of fraction of reference evapotranspiration (ETrF) (unitless)
Seasonal total of precipitation (millimeters).
Seasonal total of net evapotranspiration (ET-PPT) (millimeters).

Attribute corresponds to the month that was selected to serve as the start of the agricultural growing season. This attribute was used with END_MON to generate seasonal totals. The default value selected for the study area was “4”, corresponding to the month of April.

Attribute corresponds to the month that was selected to serve as the end of the agricultural growing season. This attribute was used with START_MON to generate seasonal totals. The default value selected for the study area was “10”, corresponding to the month of October.
Monthly total of reference evapotranspiration (ETr) for the polygon during the month of January. Reference evaporation produced from the GridMET dataset (millimeters).

overview.eaover: The entity and attribute information provided here describes the tabular data associated with the data set. Please review the detailed descriptions that are provided (the individual attribute descriptions) for information on the values that appear as fields/table entries of the data set.
overview.eadetcit: The entity and attribute information was generated by the individual and/or agency identified as the originator of the data set. Please review the rest of the metadata record for additional details and information.
